meta.title: The Evolution of Evolvability
meta.description: The player visits Richard Dawkins in his Oxford study across 10 visits. He sits at his original Macintosh, walks the player through how he created biomorphs, and ultimately arrives at a deep insight about evolution itself. Interactive breeding moments let the player experience what Dawkins experienced.
meta.source: Dawkins, R. (1988). 'The Evolution of Evolvability.' Artificial Life, SFI Studies in the Sciences of Complexity.

visits.title: Artificial Life
visits.summary: Dawkins introduces himself, explains why he built biomorphs, and lays out Weismann's principle.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: Ah, come in! I was just tinkering with something on the Mac.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: You know, a title like 'The Evolution of Evolvability' ought to be anathema to a radical neo-Darwinian like me.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: But I've been led to think differently. All because of creating computer models of artificial life.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: Not as a formal model of real life, mind you. As a generator of insight.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: I created a world of two-dimensional artificial organisms on the screen. I call them biomorphs.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: Borrowed the word from Desmond Morris — he used it for the animal-like shapes in his surrealistic paintings.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: My main objective was to reduce to the barest minimum the extent to which I designed them.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: I wanted the biology to emerge. All I would design was the conditions under which it might emerge.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: The process of emergence was to be evolution by the Darwinian process: random mutation followed by nonrandom survival.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: But before any Darwinian process can get going, there has to be a bare minimum of conditions. And these I had to engineer.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: First: there must be replicators. Entities capable of self-replication, like DNA molecules.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: Second — and this is our main concern — there must be an embryology.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: The genes must influence the development of a phenotype. Some replicators must be more successful than others. The type of embryology we choose is crucial.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: That is, in fact, the key message of everything I want to tell you.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: Now, the fundamental principle of embryology in real life was formulated by Weismann.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: The key point is this: in every generation, only genes are handed on to the next generation.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: In every generation, those genes influence the phenotype. And the phenotype determines whether the genes survive to be copied again.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: Any individual born inherits genes that have succeeded in building a long series of successful phenotypes. Failed phenotypes don't pass on their genes.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: That's natural selection. It's why organisms are well adapted. It's why we're all here.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: But here's what people miss. Genes do two quite distinct things.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: They participate in embryology — building the phenotype. And they participate in genetics — getting themselves copied.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: There is a radical separation between genetics and embryology. Even some geneticists don't fully realise it.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: Consider: you could do perfectly respectable embryology on a single individual. Genetics on a single individual would be meaningless.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: So I resolved to maintain that separation in my artificial life.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: I wrote the program around two strictly separate procedures: Reproduce and Develop.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: Develop draws the phenotype. A human chooser picks the best one. Reproduce copies its genes with mutations to breed the next litter.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: A model of artificial selection, mind you — like breeding cattle. Darwin himself used that as a metaphor for natural selection.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: But come back tomorrow and I'll show you what I put inside Develop. That's where it gets interesting.

visits.title: The Embryology Problem
visits.summary: Dawkins explains why naive pixel-peppering fails and why he needed recursion.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: Good, you're back. Now — what shall we write inside the procedure Develop?

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: Genetics is straightforward. Copying genes from parent to child, introducing random errors — that's easy.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: It's embryology we have to think about carefully. How do genes build a body?

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: The first naive idea: maximum generality. The Mac screen is 85,000 pixels. Give each pixel its own gene, value 1 or 0.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: Any conceivable picture can be represented. Any pixel can mutate. In theory, you could breed anything from anything.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: Ha! Only in theory. In practice, we'd be waiting till kingdom come.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: Precisely. In practice, we'd be waiting till kingdom come.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: This 'pixel-peppering' would produce a very boring kind of artificial life. Zero-order embryology, I call it.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: The trouble is the astronomical number of nonsense patterns. The biological-looking ones are lost in a sea of static.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: So we need constraints. Constrained embryologies are better not because they have greater generality, but because they have less.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: Fewer phenotypes. Fewer genes. But each gene controls a more powerful drawing operation than colouring a single pixel.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: We could draw random lines instead of random pixels. Slight improvement. Or use mathematical formulas — polynomials whose coefficients are genes.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: Or we could enforce bilateral symmetry. Most animals are bilaterally symmetrical, after all.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: But though these are improvements, I didn't tarry long over them.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: Right from the start, I had a strong intuitive conviction about the kind of embryology I wanted.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: I wished for recursion.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: Partly because of the generality of power that recursive algorithms have. Computer scientists know this well.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: And partly because real embryology can, to a large extent, be thought of in terms of recursion. The same local rules applied over and over.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: Let me show you the procedure I ended up with. It's called Tree.

visits.title: The Tree
visits.summary: Dawkins shows the recursive Tree procedure, explains the 9 genes, and demonstrates breeding.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: Right, where were we? The Tree procedure. Let me show you.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: Tree takes a starting position, a length, a direction, and two arrays — dx and dy — that specify the shape.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: The beautiful thing: Tree calls itself. Recursively. It branches, and each branch branches, until the depth reaches zero.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: Watch what happens when I run it.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: See how it draws? Each little branch follows the same local rules. No grand blueprint for the whole body.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: Real embryology is quite like this. Each cell obeys local instructions for dividing and differentiating. When all the local instructions are obeyed together, a body results.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: The individual twigs don't 'realise' they're part of an elaborate pattern. That's the beauty of it.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: Now, what determines the shape? The dx and dy arrays, and the starting depth. These are what the genes control.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: You might think we'd need 16 genes — 8 for dx, 8 for dy. But I added a constraint: bilateral symmetry.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: Certain dx and dy values are constrained to equal each other, sometimes with opposite sign. It collapses to just 9 genes.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: Genes 1 to 3 control horizontal spread. Genes 4 to 8 control vertical shape. Gene 9 controls the depth — the number of branchings.

interactive.prompt: Here — try the sliders. Drag each gene and watch what it does to the biomorph.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: A procedure called Plug translates the 9 genes into the dx and dy arrays. Then Tree draws the result. Simple as that.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: Now for the breeding. Reproduce creates a litter of mutant offspring. Each gene might randomly nudge up or down by one.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: Develop draws each one. I choose the most interesting. Its genes go into Reproduce. The cycle continues.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: As the generations go by, the forms evolve gradually in front of me. True evolution by Darwinian selection.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: Want to have a go? Try breeding something that looks like an insect.

interactive.prompt: Click any offspring to select it as the new parent.

visits.title: Astonishing Morphologies
visits.summary: Dawkins reveals the surprising diversity that emerged and reflects on cumulative selection.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: I have to tell you — when I first started breeding, something happened that I did not expect.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: I'd deliberately not given much thought to the precise recursive algorithm. I wanted things to emerge rather than be designed.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: I had the feeling it shouldn't really matter how the genes affected development, provided it was some kind of recursive drawing rule.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: In the event, my intuition proved to have been a considerable underestimate.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: I was genuinely astonished.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: Astonished and delighted at the richness of morphological types that emerged before my eyes as I bred.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: Look at these. Notice how many look like real animals. They evolved under the selective influence of a zoologist's eye, so perhaps it's not surprising.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: Not particular animals that actually exist. But several wouldn't look out of place in a zoological textbook.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: Some I bred to resemble other things. The spitfire there. The silver coffeepot.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: This is the power of gradual cumulative selection. Step by tiny step, complex forms emerge from simple rules.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: But the rest of what I want to tell you is about what happened when I made the embryology more elaborate.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: Having arrived at our recursive embryology and found it good — are there any judicious relaxations we can make?

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: We must resist the temptation to build in known biological details. Our watchword is that as much as possible must emerge.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: But we can make use of general biological principles. Come back tomorrow and I'll show you the first one.

visits.title: Symmetry
visits.summary: Dawkins relaxes the symmetry constraint, introducing asymmetry and new planes of symmetry.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: Symmetry. That's our first enrichment.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: The basic program forces bilateral symmetry on every biomorph. What if we relax that?

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: A new gene, just two values, on and off, which switches bilateral symmetry on or off. Allowing asymmetrical biomorphs.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: Not very interesting by itself, perhaps. But it interacts with other relaxations in ways I couldn't have predicted.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: And left-right isn't the only plane of symmetry. Think about up-down symmetry. Or full four-way radial symmetry.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: A new gene can switch on up-down symmetry. Give it a third value and you get four-way radial symmetry — like a starfish.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: Now combine left-right asymmetry with up-down symmetry. Here I had a decision to make.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: Do we achieve up-down symmetry by mirror reflection? Or by rotation? I chose rotation, somewhat arbitrarily.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: That arbitrary decision will turn out to matter enormously. Remember it.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: These symmetry genes seem to have the power to add rich emergent properties without the programmer having built in contrived design.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: Here — try breeding with symmetry controls. Switch between modes mid-breeding and watch what becomes reachable.

interactive.prompt: Try switching symmetries mid-breeding. Notice how new forms become reachable.

visits.title: Segmentation
visits.summary: Dawkins adds body segments, drawing the analogy to millipedes and vertebrates.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: Symmetry isn't the only general principle from real zoology we can borrow. Today: segmentation.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: Three of the most successful phyla — vertebrates, arthropods, annelids — organise their bodies along segmental lines.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: Segments are repeated modules, running from head to tail like trucks in a train.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: A millipede really is rather like a train. You can imagine the developmental program building one segment, then running it in a repeat loop.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: The invention of segmentation was one of the major innovations in the history of life. Made at least twice, independently.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: Once in the vertebrate lineage. Once in the ancestor of annelids and arthropods.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: So I added it to the biomorph program. One new gene for segment count, another for distance between segments.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: The basic program generates a single segment. Then we run it in a repeat loop. Just like a millipede.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: Have a go. Try breeding a millipede.

interactive.prompt: Your creatures can now have body segments. Try breeding a millipede.

visits.title: Gradients and Botany
visits.summary: Dawkins adds segmental gradients and alternating asymmetry, discovering botanical forms.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: Now, a millipede's segments all look the same. But many segmented animals taper.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: Broader at the front, narrower at the back. Or narrow at each end and broad in the middle, like a woodlouse.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: It's as though the developmental repeat loop includes scaling factors that increment or decrement each pass through.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: So I allowed for gradients affecting each of the nine basic genes separately. One gradient per gene.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: The results are striking. Compare the old portfolio to the new one — segmentation has added enormously to the ecological interest.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: An embryological innovation allowing the evolution of a whole new range of types. Just as we conjecture happened in real life.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: But those animals are all symmetrical. What happens if we combine segmentation with asymmetry?

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: Here I introduced another arbitrary constraint. I decreed that successive segments should alternate their asymmetry.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: Not repeating the same one-sidedness, but flipping it each segment. Left, right, left, right.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: I did it partly to recreate symmetry at the whole-body level. And partly to make the biomorphs more botanically interesting.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: Many plants send off alternating buds, you see. And the results are — well, look for yourself.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: Botanists would have a field day with these. That one could be any number of plant species. This one looks like an inflorescence.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: When I was breeding them, I frequently had plants in my mind. See the hockey stick? The DNA helix? A dollar sign?

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: Try it with the full set of controls. Gradients, symmetry, segmentation — the whole lot.

interactive.prompt: Gradients make each segment slightly different. Watch how forms taper and flow.

visits.title: Limits of Embryology
visits.summary: Dawkins shows echinoderms, the alphabet challenge, and introduces the paper's central argument.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: Now I want to show you something that reveals the limits of all this.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: Look at my 'echinoderm' portfolio. Radially symmetrical, segmented, with gradients.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: Any zoologist will instantly spot the trouble.

options.label: They don't look like real echinoderms?

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: Exactly! Four-way radial symmetry, not five-way. The program simply can't produce five-way symmetry. It's not in the embryology.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: Well, specifically — they have four-way symmetry instead of five. Real echinoderms are pentaradial. My program can't do five.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: Huge vistas of evolutionary possibility may be kept waiting indefinitely for a major, releasing change in embryology.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: Which brings me to the alphabet. If we can breed animals, why not arbitrary shapes?

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: I tried to sign my name in biomorph script. Bred each letter by wandering through Biomorph Land until something looked right, then selectively perfecting it.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: Some letters are perfect. I and N — easy. S and A — a little cold but passable.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: D is pretty horrible. And K? I despair of ever breeding a proper K.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: I had to fake the K in my name by turning part of an H. An obvious kludge.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: Want to try? See if you can breed a K. I couldn't.

interactive.prompt: Dawkins couldn't breed a proper K. Can you?

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: And that is the point.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: There are some things that certain kinds of embryology cannot do. Or cannot easily do.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: The alphabet dramatises it. Some letter-shapes are easy, almost inevitable. Others are difficult. Others are near-impossible.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: The problems are determined by the particular embryology the program employs. A different embryology — a different subset of the alphabet becomes easy.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: Think about what that means for real life. Come back tomorrow. I want to tell you the real argument.

visits.title: Evolutionary Watersheds
visits.summary: Dawkins distinguishes genetic system changes from evolutionary watersheds and argues for the latter's importance.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: Right. The real argument. Sit down.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: Certain kinds of embryology find it difficult to generate certain kinds of organism. That's what all the biomorph work illustrates.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: It's a powerful analogy for something in real biology. But which principle, exactly? There are two main candidates.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: First, we need a distinction. There are ordinary changes within an existing genetic system — one allele replaced by another at the same locus.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: Like industrial melanism — a gene for blackness spreading through moth populations. Standard evolutionary change.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: But there are also changes to the genetic system itself. Different numbers of chromosomes. Humans and chimps have different systems — you can't precisely identify matching loci.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: Now, the changes I've been showing you — adding symmetry genes, segmentation, gradients — those are changes to the genetic system. Going from 9 genes to 13.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: But I want to argue that this is incidental. It's not the analogy I want to draw.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: Changes in genetic system are fairly commonplace. Changes in chromosome number are nearly as common as new species forming. Hundreds of millions of times.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: No. What I want to argue is that there's another class of innovation. Very rare on the geological timescale.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: I call them evolutionary watersheds.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: The invention of segmentation is a watershed. Occurred perhaps only twice in all of history.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: What's interesting about a watershed isn't whether it coincided with a change in chromosome number. What's interesting is that it opens floodgates to future evolution.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: I conjecture that the first segmented animal was a freak. A double body where its parents had a single body.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: It probably survived by the skin of its teeth. A double body isn't obviously better adapted. Quite the contrary.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: But here's what matters: its success or failure as an individual is relatively unimportant.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: What matters is that its descendant lineages were champion radiators. They radiated, speciated, gave rise to whole new phyla.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: Whether or not segmentation helped that first individual survive, it represented a change to embryology that was pregnant with evolutionary potential.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: Let that sink in. We'll finish the argument tomorrow.

visits.title: The Evolution of Evolvability
visits.summary: Dawkins arrives at the paper's central thesis: evolution selects for evolvability itself.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: Today I want to finish the argument. The most important idea I've come to through all this work.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: Not all watersheds are as dramatic as segmentation. But there may be many changes in embryology that are, to a lesser extent, evolutionarily pregnant.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: Rank embryologies by their evolutionary potential. Then imagine adaptive radiations giving way to adaptive radiations, over geological time.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: There is a kind of ratchet. Changes in embryology that happen to be evolutionarily fertile tend to last.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: The embryologies that characterise the forms of life we actually see? Those are the ones that were good at evolving.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: This is not the same as saying embryologies that produce healthy individuals last. Though that's true too.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: I'm talking about a kind of higher-level selection. A selection not for survivability, but for evolvability.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: Now, I know this sounds dangerously close to things I've argued against. It's all too easy for this argument to be used loosely.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: Sydney Brenner once ridiculed the idea of foresight in evolution. A molecule retained because it might be useful in the future.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: 'It might come in handy in the Cretaceous!'

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: I hope I won't be taken as saying anything like that. Evolution has no foresight.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: But with hindsight — those evolutionary changes in embryology that look as though they were planned with foresight are the ones that dominate successful forms of life.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: Not foresight. Hindsight.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: Perhaps natural selection favors not just successful phenotypes, but a tendency to evolve. An eagerness to radiate.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: I used to disparage 'species selection' because it's single-step selection, not cumulative. And only cumulative selection builds real complexity.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: But selection among embryologies for evolvability — this may qualify as cumulative.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: Because after a given innovation has been favoured for its evolutionary properties, it provides a different basis for new innovations.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: Evolvability ratchets up. Each watershed makes the next watershed possible.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: The tendency to evolve — to throw up variation, to radiate, to be pregnant with evolutionary potential — that is a species-level property worth selecting for.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: The world is dominated by phyla, classes and orders whose embryology equipped them to diverge and inherit the earth.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: I've always been dimly aware of this. But it's the biomorph program that really drummed it into my innermost convictions.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: Writing it. Playing with it. And above all, modifying it — watching how changes in embryology opened or closed evolutionary possibility.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: What started as an educational exercise — I was trying to teach other people — ended up teaching something to myself about real life.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: There could be less worthy uses of artificial life.

lines.speaker: dawkins
lines.text: The Mac is yours whenever you want it. Go breed something I haven't seen yet.

interactive.prompt: You now have the complete embryology. What can you evolve?
